metadata.title: Coronavirus and Probability — The media must learn how to report statistics now | by Raphael Sonabend | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Coronavirus and Probability — The media must learn how to report statistics now
metadata.description: The phrase “underlying symptoms” crops up in almost all news stories in which someone dies from what seems a common incident. Whether it’s an allergy-sufferer, or a victim of coronavirus (‘covid’)…

all_paragraphs: The phrase “underlying symptoms” crops up in almost all news stories in which someone dies from what seems a common incident. Whether it’s an allergy-sufferer, or a victim of coronavirus (‘covid’), the “underlying symptoms” phrase is used to lessen fear. Being an unfortunate combination of both a hypochondriac and a statistician, whenever I see a news article like this I immediately skim to find the relevant line and think to myself “phew, I’m okay then”. Of course this is incredibly self-centred thinking. But as long as unconditional probabilities are reported in the media, the public’s (well certainly my) sense of personal danger is heightened.
To better explain the problem I’m talking about, we’re going to have to look at the stats a little bit, I’ll keep it as basic as possible here, later we will go into a bit more detail.
Let’s say we want to predict the probability of a die landing on the number 6 when thrown, we want to know:

Which is read as “the probability that a die equals 6”. Now say we want to predict the probability of a die landing on the number 6, given that we know (for whatever reason) that it must land on a number greater than 3. Then we want to know:
Where the vertical line “|”, means “given that”.

The difference between these two equations is that the first is unconditional — we want to know the probability of an event occurring given no other information — and the second is conditional — we want to know the probability of an event occuring and conditioned on (or “given”) some other condition or event.

Where this really makes a difference is when we start talking about Bayes’ Theorem (or Bayes’ rule). Be warned: here lies maths and stats, feel free to jump ahead to “Time to Change” if you’d rather never look at an equation again.
Bayes’ Theorem is used to calculate or update a conditional probability based on other information available. The equation is:

In words: the probability of an event A occurring, given some event B, is equal to the probability of event B occurring given event A, multiplied by the probability of event A, and divided by the probability of event B. A bit of a mouthful, so let’s instead look at an example.
We will call A the event: death by coronavirus (see where I’m going with this?), and B the event: being under the age of 65. Now we have:
P(Dying from covid given being under the age of 65) = P(Being under the age of 65 given died from covid) × P(Dying from covid) / P(Being under the age of 65)

Now the harder part is to work out the probability of being under 65, given death from covid. At this point, we have to turn to the raw data. The data cannot tell us the exact mortality rate, P(C|A<65), because we don’t know who does and doesn’t have the virus, i.e. there could be many unreported cases. (This is also a problem with P(C) but I’m ignoring that for the sake of this example). However, the data can tell us exactly P(A<65|C). So, if you’re under 65 the probability of dying from COVID-19 is actually only around 0.7% by our calculations (which are in line with more accurate estimates²).

I’ve demonstrated how easy it is to obtain calculations that are actually relevant to the reader. The above example is only relevant to 92% of the population, the other 8% are equally as important. The example conditions the probability of death on age, but underlying-health may be equally as important. The probability of dying given no underlying health conditions is actually 0.9%². Of course, ideally, we would have a big model taking into account all of age, underlying health conditions, and other relevant background information, but at that point, we’re entering the realms of more advanced statistics that go beyond the scope of a short article.

I am fed up, frustrated and scared. Because despite understanding statistics I still see the same glaring headlines again and again. It’s time for more responsible reporting of statistics and I have some ideas for how this can happen.
